column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat|salience|identity|centering
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent

#Summary1=(human1) Attorney Menaka Guruswamy asks for same-sex marriage to be accommodated within the Hindu Marriage Act based on its reform as statutory law, but when the Chief Justice urges limiting the argument to the Special Marriage Act, Guruswamy appeals for the matter to be left open, pointing out the day to day rights that proceed from marriage in India which LGBTQ people are denied.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) The Supreme Court of India discusses taking an incremental approach to LGBTQ marriage rights by potentially focusing on civil unions under the Special Marriage Act while leaving broader religious marriage laws for future consideration, given evolving societal acceptance and practical implications for daily rights.

#Summary3=(gpt4o) During a legal discussion, Maneka Guruswamy argued that the Hindu Marriage Act should be interpreted as statutory law rather than personal law, while Chief Justice Chandrachud and Justice Kaul suggested using an incremental approach to societal issues such as same-sex marriage, focusing on interpretations like civil unions under the Special Marriage Act.

#Summary4=(Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) The lawyer argued that the Hindu Marriage Act is a statutory law, not a personal law, and asked the court to consider its role in interpreting laws and society's evolving acceptance of same-sex relationships.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) Dr. Guruswamy advocates for interpreting the Special Marriage Act in a gender-neutral manner to recognize civil unions, suggesting an incremental approach to address LGBTQ+ rights without fully engaging with personal laws of different religions.
#Text=Dr. Guruswamy .
#Text=My Lords , thank you .
#Text=My Lord the Chief Justice may recognize , my Lords , that the Hindu Marriage Act is not an issue necessarily of personal law : it is statutory law .
#Text=And we will demonstrate that .
#Text=The terms of the Constitution , the reform of the Hindu Marriage Act , has always been in the context of statutory law .

#Text=So , my Lords , to that extent and that extent only in the context of statutory law and making statutory law workable , because my Lords will know , my Lords , that the origin of the Hindu Marriage Act , the Hindu Code , did something that was not permitted in sacramental Hindu law , which is inter-caste marriage , in -- sagotra marriage , divorce , inheritance ...

#Text=Dr. Guruswamy , but there 's also … there may be some amount of sage wisdom in also going about our interpretative task in an incremental manner because otherwise , do we then confine ourselves only to the Hindu Marriage Act ?
#Text=What about the Parsi Marriage Act ?
#Text=What about the Muslim law ?
#Text=What about the Jews ?
#Text=What about the Buddhists ?
#Text=A lot of other communities .
#Text=Therefore , perhaps one option for the court because … the Constitution itself and the law is itself evolving .
#Text=So the court has to be mindful of the fact that we are doing by process of interpretation what you are calling upon us to do .

#Text=So there may be some element of judicial discretion in perhaps going incrementally , covering a canvas for the present , which would substantially then ... assuming that even there you are right , because you have to hear the other side , confine yourself to this incremental canvas and then allow society to evolve .
#Text=Allow Parliament 's perceptions to evolve over a period of time because Parliament is also responding to the evolution of society over a period of time .

#Text=We ca n't deny the fact that there is undoubtedly the legislative element also involved , which is why the states , the Parliament , despite … having regard to that , we need to balance out various facets .
#Text=So this might be perhaps one way forward .
#Text=The only thing I 'll say to this ...
#Text=So we do n't have to decide everything , to decide something in this case .
#Text=No , no , my Lords , I follow , I follow .
#Text=The only thing ...
#Text=Yes , my Lord ?
#Text=One is the channel pointed out by Mr. Rohatgi in a restrictive sense that only construe the Special Marriage Act .
#Text=If it founds favor with us , it 'll give us the status of marriage .
#Text=If it does not , he rightly said , you are out .
#Text=Therefore if other issues at all arise or do n't arise , will depend on how we interpret this aspect .
#Text=Other issues will survive for another day .
#Text=Or may not survive for the time being for another day , depending on what view we take on this core issue .
#Text=And in the wisdom , as the Chief Justice said , sometimes incremental changes in issues of social and societal ramifications are possibly a better course .
#Text=There is a time for everything ... there is time for some things to come .
#Text=Therefore , what was being suggested was , uh , can we , for the time being , confine it only to this limited issue ?
#Text=Do n't step into … let me complete … do n't step into Personal Law issues under different religious norms .
#Text=Do n't get into any of those issues , but only say that , can the Special Marriage Act be interpreted in a manner by reading into it a general gender - neutral situation , period .
#Text=Can I say , and perhaps you can then help us , you can assist us .

#Text=And we 'll ask the Solicitor also to assist us on how we can sort of develop the notion of a civil union which really finds recognition in our statute , namely the Special Marriage Act , you see , because now , for instance , you know , I 'm sure you would n't also deny the fact that between the time that Navtej was delivered and today , our society has found much greater acceptance , say , of same - sex relationships for the last five years that we have seen it unfold .
#Text=And that 's very positive because , you know , you find that there is a greater acceptance and acceptance in our universities .
#Text=And by the way , our universities do n't consist of only urban kids ; they also come from the smaller , smaller areas .
#Text=Yes , but there is this acceptance which is evolving .

#Text=So , you know , in this evolving consensus , the court is also playing a dialogical role to create that consensus and move towards a more equal future by being conscious of our own limitations , which you ca n't deny the legislative arena .
#Text=The only request I would make is that the question may be left open to be adjudicated .
#Text=Obviously , we 're not going to reject what we do n't .
#Text=We can always confine our canvas and then not reject .
#Text=Yes , obviously not .
#Text=And that is not necessary for the court to do at all .
#Text=The second point is simply this , that marriage is not only as if that were not …
#Text=But leave broader and broader issues for an evolving future .
#Text=Yes , but marriage is not only a question of dignity , as if that were not enough .
#Text=It is also a bouquet of rights that LGBTQ people are being denied post - Johar , right ?
#Text=Those rights are simple things : bank accounts , life insurance , medical insurance .
#Text=I for instance , frankly …
#Text=Rental accommodation ...
#Text=I can not buy SCBA medical insurance .
#Text=I am a member of the SCBA Bar .
#Text=I can not buy my family medical insurance from the SCBA .
#Text=So this is the reality of how rights are exercised .
#Text=Rights are exercised when you are able to protect your relationships .
#Text=One facet of that right is the constitutional value of dignity , equality , fraternity .
#Text=The other facet of that right is the day to day business of life , and the day to day business of life is all of those things .

#Text=Now when we look at law in India — and all common law is premised like this — that most rights flow from this notion of blood relationships , i.e. , either being born into the family or being married .
